isis.stitle: TSI 00-08-04 - Heavy Duty Command Center Instrument Cluster Diagnostics

subjectgroup.subject: Heavy Duty Command Center Instrument Cluster Diagnostics

geninfo.para: This letter provides information for the heavy duty instrument cluster operation and diagnostics for 5000, 5000i, 9000 and 9000i Models built between January 1, 1994 and January 1, 2000 excluding 9600, 9700 and 9800 Models.

The heavy duty command center cluster consists of a speedometer/tachometer module and 2 six packs of gauges. The cluster may have either a mechanical odometer or a multi-functional digital VF odometer (VFO).

The information contained in this letter will supplement and clarify the information available in Service Sections CTS-5257, CTS-5180 and CTS-5180S found in Group 08 of the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

geninfo.title: DIAGNOSTIC TOOLS
geninfo.para: The following is a description of the tools available for troubleshooting and diagnosing the heavy duty command center instrument cluster.

MPSI Pro-Link with IPC Cartridge- This tool can be used to set the internal program and exercise the data link driven gauges in the cluster. Note that this tool will exercise the gauges only if they are programmed to read from the data link.
MPSI Pro-Link with General Purpose Heavy Duty Cartridge- This tool can be used to read and display the information on the data link and verify that the cluster is displaying the data it is receiving.

EZ-Tech with IPC Software (New)-This software may be used to either exercise the data link driven gauges or program the instrument cluster. It is more user friendly than the Pro-Link tool. A training program will be provided for this tool in the near future.
EZ-Tech with 32-bit Master Diagnostics (New)-This may be used to monitor the data link. For cluster specific data link monitoring go to Sessions>>Open>>double click on Instrumentpanelcluster.ssn.

Diagnostic Flow Diagram (New)- The diagram will guide the troubleshooting effort and indicate when a diagnostic tool should be used and what test to perform. The flow diagram includes pin-outs, gauge pins, voltage levels and circuit numbers (see Figure 1 and Figure 2).

geninfo.title: Diagnostics for Frequently Asked Questions/Issues About Instrument Clusters
geninfo.para: Issue: The cluster appears to have locked up.

Diagnosis: Use one of the diagnostic tools listed in this letter to check the data link to insure that data is available. A data driven gauge will lock-up (cease to function) if the data is not available.
Issue: The cluster appears to go through diagnostic sweeps.
Diagnosis: Check for poor or intermittent power and ground feeds within the vehicle. The cluster will reset even if power or ground is removed for only a fraction of a second.
Issue: Mechanical odometer is not changing or incrementing.
Diagnosis 1: If the odometer is clicking but not changing or incrementing, either the odometer is defective or the odometer is binding in the holding bracket.
Diagnosis 2: If the odometer is not clicking, the circuit board may be defective or the cluster is not receiving vehicle speed data on the data link.
Issue: The new service cluster installed doesn't work.
Diagnosis: The installed cluster must be programmed using the Pro-Link with IPC cartridge or the EZ-Tech tool.

note.para: All cluster DIP switches must be set to "0" for the EZ-Tech program to be active.

geninfo.para: Issue: What program should be used for the cluster.
Diagnosis: The vehicle line set ticket will indicate the required program.

geninfo.title: Intermittent Problems
geninfo.para: Intermittent problems are the most difficult to diagnose but are usually caused by one of the following:

item.para: Loose connections caused by corroded, spread or improperly seated terminals.
An electrically noisy alternator causing communication problems on the data link.

The voltmeter in service clusters with date codes later than 3897 may not function properly. To remedy this, use a Pro-link or EZ-Tech tool and change the voltmeter source from data link driven to sensor driven.
When changing the VF odometer mode, the vehicle must be driven at least 1 full mile (1.6 kilometers) to retain the mode change.
The VF odometer will not retain tenths of a mile or tenths of a kilometer. It only retains whole numbers.
The VF odometer will sporadically increment in 2 tenths of a kilometer if the cluster is not programmed to metrics. The odometer is still accurate regardless of the mode to which it is set.
